comments.commentBody: @all harbe:They already know that, which may be why they haven't attacked us despite having had many reasons to do so over the years.  And, anyway, their god is our God.
This is my go to recipe for chili! The flavor is better the longer it simmers. A crowd pleaser!

It doesn't need any water added! Plenty of liquid without. Very tasty. 60 minutes of baking is sufficient, prior to adding the mozzarella. I also added a little ginger and allspice to the ground lamb.
And if disasters don't come you'll freely give the credit to Kerry and Obama.   Right?
I support Bernie, but magical asterisks In a plan are bad, always and everywhere.

The main reason to vote for Sanders is to discipline the Democratic party into actually supporting liberal policy proposals, instead of ignoring its voters and continuing to support pro-business and moderately conservative policies. I'm not sure how that aim is diminished if Sander's healthcare proposal isn't ready to be adopted on the first day of his presidency. If incrementalism is the right way forward, why isn't Hillary Clinton laying out incremental steps toward single-payer healthcare or some comparable arrangement?

That said, I think a candidate like Sanders is rightly criticizable if, as is charged, his policy really does rely on magic asterisks and is deflects attention from its actual implications. But even if that is all true, he's facing opponents who are more than wiling to do the same thing. It's one thing to say that politicians shouldn't fudge numbers in proposals to voters. It's another thing to say that my favored candidate shouldn't fudge numbers in their proposals, given that all of the other candidates fudge on their major proposals and never seem to suffer significant setbacks in their candidacy for doing so. Perhaps Americans should be persuaded that not all ineffective treatments should be part of the health system. But perhaps it's asking a lot to say that a candidate should be the one persuade them shortly before the first primary.

If you will recall the US and the USSR maintained a blustery relationship for decades. I expect the same. That was also true with china. the tie with iran will ideally follow the same path as that with china. basically it is always a money thing. We can maintain bluster and yet they can get money. I do believe that the only goal of power is money. they get money for their people. we get quiet. but the process can be difficult.
If you pound them in a large plastic bag or wrap the cooking time lessens and will cook evenly. I love that even children love this dish as well

I got rave reviews from the family. I used fresh motz and added a tomato slice which should be thin to help everything stay together. The 4 oz. of chicken had me in a quandry. I used 2.6 lbs of chicken and added more sage, including some dry sage. I cut the chicken in thirds, but some didn't cook all the way through. I will probably cut the really thick breasts in half and create more pieces. Even with pounding them out, they still didn't cook in the recipe time. Will cook again!

Brines usually involve soaking the meat in a heavily salted solution for up to 24 hours. You could add garlic and sage to this recipe. Just be sure to rinse the briNed chicken to remove the excess salt. I always brine my Thanksgiving turkey.

It's true - on a clear day. About one day a year I could see the Golden Gate Bridge from my house in San Jose.

The rain stopped and it's magical here now. There is a huge flock of robins gorging on ripe toyon berries. It sounds like an aviary. And a rainbow is encompassing much of the Bay Area. You can see the southern end of the Bay, with the Diablo Range in the background.

Yesterday, my friend Martin received a few recos for saying he doesn't understand half the things typed here by JFC and me. My friend Leapfinger, forgetting her delight 3 years ago when I unearthed from her girlhood an advert for a great place to get smoked FISH in Montreal, suggested that Martin raise that half to 75%.

JFC took umbrage at the recos, and elegantly explained one of his Comments, leaving me to flop AROUND on the deck.

So I have unreccomended the offending Martin Reply, shifting the reco to JFC's self-defense. For myself, I have no explanation, but I do agree that Martin understands everything. Sometimes, he understands what we are going to type before we type it, because he sees the grids in advance.

That is all folderol. What is important is this: The French word that appears at the end of even non-French films is FIN. It is widely understood to mean "the end." But of course, FIN is the English word for a defining body part of a FISH.

Why has no one mentioned that the brilliant Mr. Walden constructed his FISH puzzle so that the answer to the very last clue is - in a bilingual pun - FIN?

Obama barely had a plan for health care until Hillary forced him to do it. Hers was much more comprehensive. He criticized her for the mandate - and apparently that worked as he won the election. I think it was Nancy Pelosi who insisted that health reform be put on the table asap. She understood completely that it was then when they controlled the house and the Presidency or never and she was right and still did not get everything she wanted. Pretty sure Obama did not want to go there but he owed Pelosi because she strong armed the super delegates into changing their votes from Clinton to Obama. Thats just my take...
MTF, [standing ovation]

When Roger extolls diplomacy as delivering, he forgets Syria, where diplomacy merely delivered President Obama from needing to admit that his bluff on a red-line had been called. Very big deals were made of Assad’s surrender of chemical weapons that observers certified were all he had, and the destruction of those weapons.

Then what happened? Assad turned around and gassed his own people again and again with those chemical weapons that he was supposed to have turned over and that had been destroyed with such relieved enthusiasm that “diplomacy works”.

Don’t imagine that the world and particularly our adversaries have the slightest respect for a U.S. red-line. Has that increased or reduced our ability to support global stability?

“A big nation is open for business again, back in the global financial system and world oil market.” Whatever in the world makes that a GOOD thing, when that big nation unambiguously seeks its own caliphate, destabilizes the region in Syria, Yemen and elsewhere, arrays itself against Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and Israel on RELIGIOUS grounds, of all incendiary pretexts?

Another set of international observers, operating under strict limitations despite Roger’s claim that they’re the best ever negotiated, has certified Iran’s compliance with the deal. Why should people believe that they are any more accurate than they were in Syria?

Sanctions were diplomacy that was working. What we have here looks disturbingly like appeasement.

Dr. K,

This evening I read an Oxfam article in the Times http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/19/business/economy/wealth-inequality-ris...? and I also reread you essay on is the wealth gap necessary. I wish you and your colleagues would look at this question, closely. I feel like it is the heart of this next election. Incomes and wealth continue to concentrate both in the US and globally. My mentor on this issue was Mancur Olson who published a good study in 1982 which said that as the rich gained a larger slice of the pie, the total size of he pie shrank. see. The Rise and Decline of Nations 1982. If Olson was right, and I think he was ,it seems to me that that is the issue for the 2016 election. The land fares ill in a representative democracy, where tax havens are legal and our own tax code is favorable to capital gains and high income earners on payroll taxes for FICA. The drift to oligarchy is clear, Donald Trump says that he could buy Congress, and we seem to also be drifting to monopoly at a swift rate.

Alright, but at what point if you are dealing with a group of people from the same background that is different from your country and who have a different world view, do you say "we have a problem." If 1 of 1,000 is violent, it is an aberration, how about 50 / 1,000? or 100 / 1,000? or 250 / 1000? Where is the line were a country can legitimately there is a problem with this group? And if there is a problem, are they justified in subjecting that group to - increased scrutiny, or higher entrance requirements, or domestic surveillance, or out right banning of that group? Where is the line and what are appropriate responses?

These are no longer theoretical questions to be debated by philosophers in obscure journals. These are real world problems that European countries are grappling with. We should be watching how they handle this, because our turn is next.
Hot!

Please please include metric measurements in all, but especially baking formulas. Whenever I read a comment about a cake like this, so full of eggs & oil being 'dry' I suspect over packed cups of flour as the culprit. I made it with granny smiths, followed the recipe ( well less 3 TBSP oil) and we all thought it was pretty darn good.....

The men in question? There are 4.2 million Syrian refugees. The US has taken in 2,000 and promised to take in 10,000 more. An absurdly small number compared to the 800,000 refugees admitted since 9/11 (out of this group, three turned out to have terrorist connections).

This is not an essay about taking in "sexist" men, it's a philosophical exhortation to welcome the outcast written by Emmanuel Levinas and laid out by the author here. "Enjoyment of the world" is not a term for women's equality (per se) but a general term for all the pursuits of free people that become called into question in the midst of great suffering. Looking into the "human face" we, not as Americans but fellow humans, have a duty to offer hospitality.

"A Muslim man's wants" this is NOT what the subject of this essay.

This Nigella Lawson contribution has given a new wrinkle against my moratorium of no more roast chicken recipes/techniques.  Yes, I am adding this recipe, as it is that special and unique.  The Rosemary/ garlic flavors, and the warmth of black peppery heat, were all present.  But the texture and moistness of buttermilk infused meat was transcendent. I marinated for 2 days, and am never going back! I may try using the equivalent of all dark meat next time, in the form of thighs..maybe a wing too.

May I post on my post?  I have made this pie, 3 times within a 2 week period.  My 3rd. rendition was the "charm" I had pondered.  I did not separate and treat the whites and yolks as separate entities.  The  out of shell whole eggs were simply whisked and added to the filling, like most of the pumpkin pies I have baked over the years.  This was the best pie yet!

Saudi Arabia supports Sunni terrorists including ISIS. Should we sever diplomatic relations or preserve the relationship and keep the lines of communications open, in the hope that we can convince them to change? One thing is certain, no one ever changed anyone's mind by not talking to them.

Just made these tonight and they're insanely good. Very sweet, if you wanted to cut back a bit on the sugar it would probably be fine. The batter alone is great, why bother baking! They've very fudgey and a bit greasy due to all the butter.  I let them sit on paper towels for a bit and it worked nicely. I WILL make these again.

Waffling? How is the moral imperative to recognize the suffering of others and offer them hospitality as a mark of human solidarity waffling. All the political backbiting and grandstanding is waffling.

And 10,000 refugees is "expensive"? .004% of the American population? We have taken in almost a million refugees since 9/11, I don't recall any banks being broken. Can you point to any fiscal hardships? On the contrary, while Europe struggles to make a 2.2 fertility rate to maintain population, the U.S. easily absorbs and assimilates hard working refugees who join the society and contribute to the general welfare and bail out the rest of us paying for the Baby Boom in retirement.

How do you know how much resettlement costs? Not too much. Much of this work is outsourced to groups like Catholic Charities and furniture, etc. is largely donated. The government resttlement period is six months and most charities do not help more than three or four months. I helped some families get settled through Catholic Charities, and the refugees I met were eager to jump in to American society, start working and start building their lives. Many of them have family support or support among their ethnic group. And the government gives each refugee less than a grand to get settled.

The bottom line: refugees are forced to flee. And like the essay notes, we as human beings have a duty to welcome them. They give back far more than "we" put in for them.

"Waffling"? I haven't seen it.
As soon as the Post Office takes over the pharma industry you'll see innovation go "pffffft"

No, jackinnj, I've a whole file here, a la Joe McCarthy, of top research pharmacologists who'd be happy to work for a $million/yr in NIH state-of-the-art labs, entirely bypassing the overpaid paper-shufflers in the current industry's bloated executive suites.

Ellison, Wolfram, and author Austin Frakt have direct access to names and at least estimated salaries+benefits packages for each of the top ten executives at SmithKlein Beecham, Merck, Pfizer, Bristol-Meyer Squibb, PHARMA, et al. and their major lobbying agencies. Such information is indispensable to any view any reader attempts to form on this topic, and should be provided prominently in the body of such an article.

"Last November, an executive of the largest advocacy group for drug manufacturers suggested that a drug’s price should be commensurate with the value it provides."

"The value it provides" to whom?

Soon as the pharmaceutical industry is nationalized, to the eternal benefit of all citizens, the lucrative private impulse to greed and extortion is removed from any equation concerning the health of Americans.
